Harsh Mahajan 
harshmahajan2345@gmail.com 
+91 9289039721 
7th August 2024 
To, 
The Head of Department 
Department of Computer Science and Engineering 
Maharaja Surajmal Institute Of Technology 
New Delhi 
Subject: Request for Leave for August 2024  
Dear Sir/Madam, 
I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to formally request a 
leave of absence for the entire month of August 2024 to undertake a 
software engineering internship with KLJ Group, located in 
Gurugram. This internship offers a valuable opportunity for 
professional development and aligns closely with my academic and 
career objectives. 
I am committed to staying on top of my academic responsibilities and 
have arranged to keep up with coursework and assignments during 
my leave. I will ensure a smooth transition and catch up on any 
missed work upon my return. 
I would greatly appreciate your consideration of my request. Thank 
you for your understanding and support. 
Yours sincerely, 
 
 
Harsh Mahajan 
Enrollment Number: 7115002722 
Department: B-Tech CSE-II 
3rd Year, 5th Semester

To, 
The CDC Cell  
Vivekanand Institute of Professional Studies -Technical Campus  
New Delhi  
Subject: Request for Leave from 5th August  to 1st September  
Respected Sir/Madam,  
I am writing to formally request a leave of absence from 5th 
August  to 1st September  to participate in an internship with KLJ 
group. This opportunity is integral to my professional 
development and is aligned with my academic objectives.  
I am committed to maintaining my academic performance and 
attendance upon my return. I have made arrangements to stay 
current with coursework and assignments during my leave to 
ensure continuity in my studies.  
Thank you for considering my request.  
Yours sincerely,  
 
Soumil Suri  
Enrollment Number -02717 711622  
Department - B-tech  AIML -A 
5th semester

Internship Offer from KLJ Resources Limited
1 message
Deepak Uniyal <deepakuniy al@kljindia.com> Thu, 11 Jul 2024 at 5:01 pm
To: soumilsuri@gmail.com
Cc: HIM ANI TIWARI <himani@kljindia.com>, Jy otsana Dhawan <jy otsana@kljindia.com>, Megha Dugar <mdugar@kljindia.com>, Aman
Bhut oria <aman@kljindia.com>, Sanjiv Go yal <sanjiv@kljindia.com>, amit.gupta@cor alba yadvisor y.com
<amit.gupta@cor alba yadvisor y.com>
Mr. Soumil Suri
19/21-B, Tilak Nagar,
New Delhi - 110018
 
Dear Soumil,
 
We were highly impressed by your academic credentials and enthusiasm to learn during the selection process. We
are delighted to inform you that you have been selected as a Machine Learning & AI Intern for Machine Learning &
AI programme hence we are excited to welcome you to KLJ Group.
 
Your internship will continue for two to three months tenure which may be extended based on the requirement of
the internship assignment assigned to you, subject to your availability. This is a paid internship and you will be
receiving a monthly stipend as per the company policy. Your work schedule is going to be Monday to Saturday, from
9.30 A.M. to 6.00 P.M.
 
During your internship, you will support the technology development team with various tasks. You will be working
under the direct supervision of the Technical Advisor, who will guide, mentor and support you throughout your
internship.
 
Please note that this offer does not guarantee full-time employment with our organization. However, based on your
performance during the internship you may receive a pre-placement offer.
 
We request you to carefully review all the information mentioned in this letter. If you have any questions or require
any further clariﬁcation, please feel free to contact with Ms. Megha Dugar at mdugar@kljindia.com.  
 
We kindly request you to please acknowledge this Offer / E-Mail.
 
Sincerely,
 
DEEPAK UNIYAL
Lead - HR (Corporate)
KLJ Resources Limited

Dear Harsh,
 
We were highly impressed by your academic credentials and enthusiasm to learn during the selection
process. We are delighted to inform you that you have been selected as a Software Engineering
Intern (SWE) Intern for Software Engineering programme hence we are excited to welcome you to
KLJ Group.
 
Your internship will continue for two to three months tenure which may be extended based on the
requirement of the internship assignment assigned to you, subject to your availability. This is a paid
internship and you will be receiving a monthly stipend as per the company policy. Your work
schedule is going to be Monday to Saturday, from 9.30 A.M. to 6.00 P.M.
 
During your internship, you will support the software and technology development team with various
tasks. You will be working under the direct supervision of the Technical Advisor, who will guide,
mentor and support you throughout your internship.
 
Please note that this oﬀer does not guarantee full-time employment with our organization. However,
based on your performance during the internship you may receive a pre-placement oﬀer.
 
We request you to carefully review all the information mentioned in this letter. If you have any

We kindly request you to please acknowledge this Oﬀer / E-Mail.

Benzene
Asian Benzene: Prices fall with weaker upstream 
markets
 US-Asia spread at $130/mt
 JG Summit releases term sale tender for 15,000 mt or 
75,000 mt
Asian benzene prices fell $5/mt on the session to $998.33/mt 
FOB Korea, amid weaker performance in upstream markets.
Upstream, the front month ICE Brent futures contract fell 
26 cents/b on the session to $85.10/b. Platts assessed the 
C+F Japan naphtha marker $6.25/mt lower on the session at 
$699.50/mt.
Two deals were observed during the Platts Market On Close 
assessment process for FOB Korea, where Tricon bought H2 
August FOB Korea from TotalEnergies at $1,006/mt, and GS 
Caltex bought September FOB Korea from TotalEnergies at 
$994.50/mt.
Market participants expect supply to be more plentiful, with 
South Korean producers coming back from turnaround activity 
and also higher inventories in China. While no firm bids or offers 
were heard on the day for CFR China, market sources suggested 
that recent discussions were heard at premiums of around $37-
$38/mt against the September weekly Mean of Platts Korea base 
price for September arrival cargoes.
“Supply feels more plentiful nowadays, ” said a buyer in China.
Amid a slowdown in demand as downstream units in China are 
undergoing a turnaround season, some expect prices to continue 
the downward trend, though others have pointed out that an 
opening arbitrage opportunity to the US would provide prices 
some level of support.
The Asia-US spread, calculated as the difference between the 
FOB Korea marker and the US DDP M2 marker, stands at $130/mt 
as of the Asian close on July 19.
In tender news, the Philippines’ JG Summit Olefins Corporation 
has released a benzene term sale tender, FOB Batangas, for 
either 15,000 mt or 75,000 mt, loading over October 2024 
to December 2024 or over October 2024 to December 2026, 
according to market sources.
Customs statistics from South Korea indicate that the country 
exported 223,187 mt of benzene in June, increasing 11.6% from

India Toluene: Limited import activity amid healthy 
inventory
 Domestic prices heard stable
 Sep ICE Brent crude futures slip 26 cents/b
Domestic ex-Kandla toluene prices remained stable on the 
day July 19, reportedly at Rupee 83-84/kg, while ex-Mumbai 
prices were at Rupee 85/kg.
Domestic sellers are trying to sell at higher prices because the 
material previously imported at a lower cost has depleted, and 
they are now offering material that was imported at a higher cost, 
an India-based trader said.
Buyer’s interest remains subdued, despite sellers significantly 
reducing their offers, according to a trader. He added that the 
healthy domestic inventory and weak demand resisted buyers 
from importing. Around 8,000 mt of toluene was expected to 
unload from South Korea in the week starting July 22.
Meanwhile, a seller mentioned that there was resistance to sell 
to India at a premium below $100/mt. “We are looking to sell into 
Southeast Asia market as prices are now almost similar to India 
and netbacks from selling into India are thin. Margins are negative 
for sellers when selling at $100/mt premium, ” a trader said.
The outright price was assessed at $977/mt, down $1/mt on 
the day, based on the FOB Korea marker. The FOB Korea marker 
was assessed at $879/mt, down $1/mt on the day.
Front-month ICE September Brent futures slipped 26 cents/b 
from the previous close to $85.10/b at the Asian close July 19.

Asian Solvent MX: FOB Korea falls $23/mt on week 
as offers emerge
 Aromatics markets mostly lower
 China MX inventory shrinks further
Asian solvent-grade mixed xylene fell $23/mt week on week 
to $877/mt FOB Korea on July 19, with other markers also moving 
lower amid generally lower prices in related markets and as 
offers for August-loading cargoes were unchallenged by bids.Asian aromatics markets were mostly moving lower week on 
week with naphtha prices weakening over the period. Toluene 
FOB Korea shed $9/mt at $879/mt on July 19, while isomer-grade 
mixed xylene fell $12.50/mt to $906.50/mt FOB Korea.
However, the markets were not all looking soft as import prices 
to China seemed workable at the moment, with buy ideas for 
August arrivals heard around $900-$915/mt CFR China. In China, 
the inventory level of MX was shrinking further with some market 
sources saying levels in east China were below or just above 
30,000 mt, compared to around 35,000 mt the week before.
But the Southeast Asia market still seemed soft and 
relatively thin.
In related market news, South Korea’s Lotte Chemical shut its 
naphtha-fed steam cracker and related benzene-toluene-xylene 
unit in Daesan early July 18 following a power failure, sources 
close to the company said.
The company’s steam cracker is able to produce 1.1 million mt/
year of ethylene and 550,000 mt/year of propylene. A company 
source said its butadiene production is also coming down 
following the emergency shutdown. The company has a 190,000 
mt/year butadiene plant in Daesan.
“The NCC and BTX units are both down, ” one of the sources 
said. “Restart is expected on July 20, ” the source added.
Another source close to the company said: “I know that it is 
the gas turbine generator [trip]. ”
The Daesan unit was running at 80% capacity in July, similar 
to its BTX unit in Yeosu, S&P Global Commodity Insights reported 
earlier. Inventories have been low, with both units holding around 
5,000 mt of toluene, sources said.
The aromatics plant in Daesan can produce 240,000 mt/year 
of benzene, 120,000 mt/year of toluene and 60,000 mt/year of 
mixed xylenes.

Paraxylene
Asian Paraxylene: Prices drop as supply concerns 
resurface
 Curbing supplies remains a challenge
 PTA producers grapple with high freight rates
Asian paraxylene prices fell on the day July 19 amid fresh 
concerns of excess supplies prevailing in the Asian market.
Platts assessed Asian PX down $3.83/mt on the day 
at $1,008.50/mt CFR Taiwan/China on July 19, S&P Global 
Commodity Insights data showed.
PX prices declined, shedding light on the excess spot volumes 
in the market with a limited likelihood of any major reduction in 
production.
A trader in Singapore said that despite the weakness in 
demand for PX, producers may find it hard to slash production.
“For PX and benzene, it is difficult to cut operation rates as 
mogas [is] not performing, ” the trader said.
As the hype around gasoline blending and the US summer 
driving season is over, producers are expected to channel 
aromatics production around Asia itself, market sources said.
“From November [trading cycle] onward, I don’t see PX and benzene going to [the] gasoline pool, ” the trader in 
Singapore said.
Meanwhile, purified terephthalic acid producers are 
concerned as container freight costs have surged sharply, a 
producer in Asia said.
The sharp rise in container shipping costs is now pushing 
producers to opt for breakbulk shipping instead, some 
shipbrokers said.
“I think everyone is switching to breakbulk due to container 
fees being high, ” the producer in Asia said.
Furthermore, the rise in freight rates is impacting buying 
trends as well, the producer added.
“Because they need volumes for breakbulk, customers are 
trying to combine [import] volumes for two months [of] loading, ” 
the producer noted.
The Asian PX Platts Market on Close assessment process 
July 19 saw several bids and offers for September- and October-
delivery cargoes.

Asian Iso-MX: Falls $11.50-$12.50/mt on week with 
lower PX
 PX falls $17 .17/mt on week
 China inventory shrinks further
Asian isomer-grade mixed xylene fell $12.50/mt on the week 
to $906.50/mt FOB Korea, to $921.50/mt CFR Taiwan and down 
$11.50/mt at $931.50/mt CFR China on July 19, with downstream 
paraxylene also moving lower from the previous week.
PX was down $17 .17/mt at $1,008.50/mt CFR Taiwan/China on 
July 19, and the PX price also moved lower by $3.83/mt day on day.
As a result, the PX-MX spread ended the week at $102/mt, 
narrowing from $106.67/mt on July 12.
A trader said the shrinking spread between PX and MX could 
be the result of increased run rates at PX plants, which were 
consuming more MX.
In China, the inventory level of MX was shrinking further with 
some market sources saying levels in east China were below 
or just above 30,000 mt, compared to around 35,000 mt the 
week before.
The Platts domestic China ex-tank assessment was assessed 
down Yuan 23.33/mt day on day at Yuan 7 ,835/mt on July 19, or about $943.50/mt on an import-parity basis.
Meanwhile in news during the week, South Korea’s exports 
of isomer-MX rose 3.2% year on year in the first half of 2024 to 
581,431 mt as exports, especially to the US, more than doubled by 
136,308 mt to 212,253 mt, customs data released July 15 shows.
A bullish outlook for the gasoline peak demand season led to 
large volumes of MX being shipped to the US early in the year, 
but with gasoline margins and gasoline-related demand tumbling 
over May-June, the arbitrage to the US has since closed and the 
outlook shifted to a bearish gear.

The Platts domestic China ex-tank assessment was assessed 
down Yuan 23.33/mt day on day at Yuan 7 ,835/mt on July 19, or about $943.50/mt on an import-parity basis.
Meanwhile in news during the week, South Korea’s exports 
of isomer-MX rose 3.2% year on year in the first half of 2024 to 
581,431 mt as exports, especially to the US, more than doubled by 
136,308 mt to 212,253 mt, customs data released July 15 shows.
A bullish outlook for the gasoline peak demand season led to 
large volumes of MX being shipped to the US early in the year, 
but with gasoline margins and gasoline-related demand tumbling 
over May-June, the arbitrage to the US has since closed and the 
outlook shifted to a bearish gear.
On the flip side, exports from South Korea to China over the 
same period plunged 40.9% year on year to 213,122 mt, while 
exports to Taiwan and India have both increased.
South Korea’s isomer-MX imports, which are almost entirely 
from Japan, also shrunk in the first six months of the year by 
36.6% to 146,723 mt, the customs data showed.
Looking at June isomer-MX exports from South Korea, the 
total volume was 84,276 mt, with the largest volume shipped to 
the US at 41,580 mt, followed by China at 19,034 mt.

discussions. Toward the later part of the day, tradable indications

Styrene
Asian Styrene Monomer: Prices fall in line with 
futures
 Crude, China styrene futures fall
 Inventories rise on week
Platts assessed Asian styrene monomer down $6/mt day on day 
at $1,128.50/mt CFR China, $1,113.50/mt FOB Korea and $1,158.50/mt 
CFR Taiwan, respectively, July 19.
SM futures were lower on the day. August contracts were 
discussed around Yuan 9,225/mt at around 3 pm Singapore time 
July 19, compared with about Yuan 9,287/mt at 3 pm July 18. 
September futures slipped to Yuan 9,114/mt from Yuan 9,183/mt the 
previous day.
The domestic ethylbenzene market in China was softer, 
widening the spread to the downstream China domestic styrene 
monomer to Yuan 920/mt. Platts assessed the China domestic ethylbenzene spot price down at Yuan 8,611/mt.
Trading sources attributed the weaker demand for styrene to 
lower operating rates for ABS and PS plants. The reduced demand 
has led to a surplus of styrene in the market, which typically puts 
downward pressure on styrene prices.
Styrene inventory in China was increasing week on week, 
trading sources said. In East China, the stocks rose by 5,900 mt 
from a week earlier to 38,700 mt in the week ended July 19, trading 
sources added.
“[Some are] struggling from high inventory issue, which is a 
direct impact of low demand in India, ” a trader said.
There was an H2 August-September buying indication heard at 
around CFR China plus $15/mt on CFR Korea basis, sources said. No 
trades were reported.
Upstream, Platts assessed Asian benzene down around $5/mt 
on the day July 19.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Sources said inventories remain on the higher side locally and 
demand is sluggish.
There were fewer import offers heard as sellers are not keen 
on selling due to weak market sentiment in India.
However, a trader said there is some positive change in the 
fundamentals and prices may get a push from supply side in the 
coming days.
“As domestic players were trying to reduce their volumes at 
below cost, around 15,000 mt inventory is being exported and 
we are seeing some positive effect in the market already, ” the 
trader said.
“We are also seeing some uptrend in Kandla offers, the 
oversupply situation seems to be gradually changing, ” the 
source added.
The domestic traders were heard to discuss domestic prices 
at Rupee 97-100/kg, ex-Kandla, sources said.
Meanwhile, the adjacent markets in the region were softer.

Caprolactam
Asian caprolactam: Support from upstream 
benzene weakens
 Offer levels edge lower
 Downward pressure on prices expected in coming weeks
Asian caprolactam prices were assessed $5/mt lower in the 
week ending Jul 18, amid lower offers heard.
Upstream, benzene prices fell $17 .34/mt on the week to 
$1,003.33/mt FOB Korea. Ammonia prices gained $10/mt on the 
week, with Platts’ last assessment of ammonia prices at $460/mt 
Far East Asia on July 17 .
Market participants remained on the sidelines in the week 
ending July 18, with muted activity heard.
In China, price discussions have fallen sharply, said market 
sources, with the rest of the market possibility following suit in 
the coming weeks.
“I’ve heard that the domestic China market has fallen to an equivalent of $1,550/mt, next week the CFR Far East Asia spot 
market could possibly tumble by another $50-$100/mt, ” said a 
market source.
Another market source said that caprolactam is gaining some 
support from stable demand in downstream nylon-6 resins, which 
could limit the fall in prices as caprolactam starts to lose support 
from falling benzene prices.
“Buyers are still in a wait-and-see mode. There have been 
offers but my price ideas are on the conservative side, ” said a 
buyer in Taiwan, who added that an offer around $1,660/mt was 
received this week.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

 Slabstock polyols down $40/mt on week
 Domestic prices heard unchanged
Asian polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanate was stable 
on the week July 19, with offers heard at the similar level from 
the last week. However, slabstock polyol prices were lower in 
the week to July 19, followed by weakened domestic prices amid 
weak demand due to the monsoons.
Platts assessed CFR India polymeric MDI stable on the week 
at $2,375/mt July 19.
Polymeric MDI offers remained at the similar level from last 
week and were heard in the range of $2,380-$2,400/mt CFR India, 
while India ex-tank offers were firm and heard around Rupees 
210-218/kg during the week.
Container freight discussion was also unchanged from the last 
week with prices heard around $3,000-$3,500/TEU from Taiwan/
Thailand to India and $3,500-$4,000/TEU from South Korea 
to India.
The domestic prices were firm as the import offers still remain 
unchanged, market sources said.
The offers were expected to come down as container freight 
rates improved, but sellers have maintained the offers citing 
vessels unavailability and delays as the reason, a market source 
said, adding that the material supply had been an issue. However 
the supply-demand spread couldn’t widen much as the demand 
reduces from normal levels during the monsoons.
Platts assessed CFR India slabstock polyol down $40/mt on 
the week at $1,455/mt.

Methanol
Asian Methanol: Prices soften on ample supply, 
tepid demand
 SE Asia end users focus on term obligations
 Higher palm oil prices deter demand for biodiesel, methanol
 Sep ZCE down Yuan 80/mt on week
Asian methanol prices closed the week July 19 lower on the 
back of ample supply and slow demand.
A surfeit of Middle East cargoes heading for the Indian 
methanol market led some sellers to reconsider their positions 
and offer some cargoes in the Southeast Asian methanol market 
for August.A deal for a cargo arriving in the second-half of August was 
concluded at $352/mt CFR Singapore, which was superseded by 
an offer at $350/mt CFR Singapore.
Spot demand for methanol at Southeast Asian main ports 
was tepid as end users were committed to fulfilling their term 
obligations or had no space in their tanks for spot cargoes.
Methanol demand from regional biodiesel producers was 
tepid as palm methyl ester prices were $305.79/mt higher than 
gasoil, data from S&P Global Commodity Insights showed.
“It’s just cheaper to burn gasoil than biodiesel, ” said a trader.
Methanol is one of the feedstocks of biodiesel.
In China, an early-week rally fizzled out midweek when market 
data showed a 6.23% on week rise in methanol inventory to 
680,900 mt on July 17 .
Domestic methanol prices in east China fell for three 
continuous days as expectations of ample methanol supply 
arriving in China in August weighed on the market sentiment.
“China imports are expected to be higher in August, ” a 
trader said.
The actively-traded September methanol futures contract on 
the Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange fell Yuan 32/mt or $4.40/mt 
day on day from the previous close and Yuan 80/mt lower on the 
week at Yuan 2,493/mt July 19.
Platts assessed CFR China $2/mt lower day on day at 
$286.50/mt and CFR Southeast Asia methanol price down $1/mt 
on the day at $350/mt July 19.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

India Methanol: Rebounds slightly following losses 
in a weak market
 Iranian volumes expected to land in Aug
 Weak buying interest weighs on prices
Indian methanol prices rose marginally July 19, after sharp 
declines the previous week, with market fundamentals weak amid 
expectations of cargo inflows from Iran in August.
Indian traders were under selling pressure, with local ex-
tank discussions heard in the Rupee 25-25.25/kg range at the 
Kandla and Mumbai ports. “End-users are bidding too low. 
We are struggling to sell even at Rupee 25.25/kg ex-tank, ” an 
importer said.
Hazira port offers were heard in the Rupee 25.75-26/kg range, 
against buying interest heard at Rupee 25.50/kg. Import parity levels were in the $279-$285/mt range, Platts data showed. “We 
have stopped selling and [are] trying to buy material from local 
traders amid a weaker ex-tank market. The Kandla port inventory 
is concentrated in few hands, ” a trader said.
About 38,560 mt methanol was expected to arrive in Mumbai 
in the week ending July 26.

About 38,560 mt methanol was expected to arrive in Mumbai 
in the week ending July 26. A 17 ,000 mt Iranian cargo was 
expected to arrive at the Kandla port by July 22, according to 
trade sources. “August is long with several cargoes from Iran are 
expected into India, ” said a trade source.
Meanwhile, material lifting from ports remained consistent 
with several auctions heard concluded in the week ended July 19.
CFR discussions were heard in a wide range. A 5,000 mt 
second-half August-arrival trade was heard at $275/mt CFR India, 
letter of credit 30 days. Another 3,000 mt was heard sold on bond 
transfer basis to an end-user. An H1 August loading, Aug. 15-20 
arrival, 5000 mt trade was done at $283/mt CFR India. Two bids 
were heard — one at $273/mt and another at $280/mt CFR India.
“We think the market has already hit a bottom, ” an 
importer said.
Sellers were on the sidelined because of weaker price 
realization in India. “We would prefer not to sell and wait, ” a 
trader said.
Platts assessed the CFR India methanol price higher by 50 
cents/mt on the day at $280.50/mt on July 19.
In the adjacent market, Platts assessed CFR China methanol 
down $2/mt on the day at $286.50/mt and CFR Southeast Asia 
methanol $1/mt lower on the session at $350/mt.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Singapore on July 19, in line with lower crude oil futures and 
narrower gasoline margins.

to $85.10/b at 0830 GMT . However, the gasoline spread to crude

Platts assessed Asian ethylene stable on the day at $857/
mt CFR Northeast Asia and $925/mt CFR Southeast Asia July 19, 
on thin price indications, with most discussions remaining on a floating basis, priced off publications, a producer said.
In South Korea, prices were assessed slightly firmer due to 
turnarounds.
In Japan, Idemitsu Kosan shut its naphtha-fed steam cracker 
in Tokuyama July 15 amid some problems, a company source 
said July 18. The restart timeline for the cracker was unclear. The 
cracker can produce 623,000 mt/year of ethylene.
Japan’s Maruzen Petrochemical plans to restart its naphtha-
fed steam cracker in Chiba late July after annual maintenance, 
delaying from the original mid-July timeline, a company source 
said July 19.
The cracker, which can produce 550,000 mt/year of ethylene 
and 230,000 mt/year of propylene, was shut around mid-May for 
maintenance. It is unclear why the cracker restart has been delayed.
In South Korea, Lotte Chemical shut its naphtha-fed steam 
cracker and related benzene-toluene-xylene unit in Daesan early 
July 18 following a power failure, sources close to the company 
said. The cracker can produce 1.1 million mt/year of ethylene. It is 
due to be restarted July 20.
Market sources said the market impact from the unplanned 
outages was reported to be minimum, as spot demand remained 
sluggish amid negative margins.

will be operating at around 80%-100% capacity, depending on the 
downstream demand.

It is unclear why the cracker restart has been delayed.
In South Korea, Lotte Chemical shut its naphtha-fed steam 
cracker and related benzene-toluene-xylene unit in Daesan early 
July 18 following a power failure, sources close to the company 
said. The cracker can produce 1.1 million mt/year of ethylene. It is 
due to be restarted July 20.
Market sources said the market impact from the unplanned 
outages was reported to be minimum, as spot demand remained 
sluggish amid negative margins.
Taiwan’s Formosa Petrochemical plans to shut its No. 2 steam 
cracker in Mailiao in August following poor olefin production 
margins, a company official said. Meanwhile, the No. 3 cracker 
will be operating at around 80%-100% capacity, depending on the 
downstream demand.
Formosa previously shut the No. 1 cracker for maintenance 
and planned to keep it offline until early August.
However, it has no plans to restart the unit as yet, as razor-thin 
olefin margins continue to impede the market, the source said, 
adding that the No. 1 and 2 crackers will likely remain shut unless 
there is an improvement in downstream demand.
Formosa’s No. 1 cracker is able to produce 700,000 mt/year of 
ethylene, 350,000 mt/year of propylene and 109,000 mt/year of 
butadiene, while the No. 2 unit has an output of up to 1.03 million 
mt/year of ethylene, 515,000 mt/year of propylene and 162,000 
mt/year of butadiene.
Meanwhile, the No. 3 cracker has a capacity of 1.2 million mt/
year of ethylene, 600,000 mt/year of propylene, and 180,000 mt/
year of butadiene.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Propylene
Asian Propylene: Prices mixed amid tighter 
Japanese supplies, SE Asian supplies recover
 Mixed sentiments regarding SE Asian propylene complex
 Poor downstream market demand in Taiwan heard
Asian propylene prices were mixed in the week to July 19, with 
tighter supply leading to an increase in FOB Japan, while the other Asian markers are largely stable as market participants 
assess the supply-demand situation in Southeast Asia.
The Southeast Asian market appeared to have stabilized from 
a previous increase in prices across the last two weeks, with a 
mix or pressurized and refrigerated cargoes being traded in the 
spot market.
Nonetheless, short-term views on the SE Asian propylene 
complex were mixed. Some market participants find that prices 
have peaked and are expecting a downward correction moving 
forward, while others remain optimistic that pockets of demand 
will continue to support the market.
“Buyers are now covered, ” a Singapore-based source said, 
commenting that major regional exporters are continuing to sell 
propylene cargoes, pointing toward supply being supported.
“People’s buying ideas are now lower ... and PDH run rates in 
China are still high, ” the market source added.
The Platts-assessed CFR Southeast Asian marker remained 
unchanged on the week at $910/mt on July 19.
Meanwhile, in Taiwan, “there is not much support from 
downstream [markets like polypropylene], [demand for propylene 
is] super weak now, ” a Taiwan-based source said.
Platts assessed the CFR Taiwan marker unchanged on the 
week at $860/mt.
The Shandong propylene price rose Yuan 50/mt on the day 
to Yuan 7 ,230/mt on July 19, while the eastern China price was 
unchanged at Yuan 7 ,175/mt over the same period.
Platts assessed the propylene CFR China marker unchanged 
on the day and on the week, at $875/mt on July 19, while the 
Asian polypropylene-propylene spread was assessed at $40/mt, 
below the typical breakeven spread of $150/mt.
In cracker news, Japan’s Maruzen Petrochemical plans to 
restart its naphtha-fed steam cracker in Chiba late July after 
annual maintenance, delaying from the original mid-July timeline, 
S&P Global Commodity Insights reported previously.
The cracker, which can produce 550,000 mt/year of ethylene 
and 230,000 mt/year of propylene, was shut around mid-May 
for maintenance. It is unclear why the cracker restart has been 
delayed.

Asian Butadiene: Stable to $20/mt higher on 
demand from Japan
 Some 4,000 mt demand covered in Japan
 SE Asia tender closes at minus $40-$50/mt
Platts assessed Asian butadiene stable to $20/mt higher day 
on day and week on week July 19, as the market was partially 
driven by demand in Japan, while supplies were available in 
Southeast Asia.
Platts assessed CFR China butadiene stable day on day at 
$1,560/mt July 19 and CFR Northeast Asia up $20/mt at $1,570/
mt during the same period. Platts assessed FOB Korea butadiene 
$10/mt higher day on day at $1,550/mt July 19.
Asia’s butadiene market sentiment improved due to increased 
spot demand in Japan, following an unplanned shutdown of 
Idemitsu Kosan’s steam cracker in Tokuyama. Market sources 
estimated that around 4,000 mt of spot butadiene demand 
emerged due to the shutdown, which was promptly covered 
within the week.
Consequently, demand for South Korea-origin cargoes surged 
as Japanese end-users preferred purchasing from South Korea.
A 2,000-mt spot cargo was heard to have been traded at 
$1,720/mt FOB Korea for mid-August. Some China-origin cargoes 
were reported to have been done at $1,590-$1,600/mt FOB China 
under a swap deal with South Korea-origin cargoes.
Some market sources said supplies in NE Asia tightened 
temporarily following the shutdown.
On the other hand, supplies from Southeast Asia were 
available, with Malaysia’s Titan issuing a tender to sell a 2,000-
mt butadiene cargo for Aug. 24-28 loading on an FOB Pasir 
Gudang basis.
Some market sources said the cargo was sold at a discount of 
$40-$50/mt based on a CFR NE Asia-linked pricing formula, on an 
FOB SE Asia basis, slightly weaker than the last deal done heard 
at minus $40-$45/mt.
Trading sources said more spot cargoes are seen to be 
available from Malaysia amid a downstream rubber plant 
shutdown. Deepsea supplies from Europe are also due to arrive

offers
 Aug offers to be slashed amid falling freight rates
 Asia players expect BIS delay
Asian polyvinyl chloride was assessed stable-to-$10/mt-
lower on the week July 17 ahead of fresh offer announcement 
for August.
Platts assessed the CFR China PVC price stable on the week 
at $795/mt July 17 , while CFR Southeast Asia price was down $10/
mt to $825/mt during the same period, according to S&P Global 
Commodity Insights data.
Spot price discussions in the Asian PVC market were scarce 
this week ahead of fresh offer announcement for August. Market 
participants now expect fresh offers for August to be lowered 
from a month earlier, reflecting bearish demand as well as falling 
container freight rates.
For July, monthly PVC offers were increased $150/mt from

a month earlier to $980/mt CFR India, while those basis CFR

freight rates.
A market source said Asia’s container market has been 
steaming off, with a rate between China and India route heard at 
$100-$130/mt compared to $180/mt a month earlier. Reflecting

India PVC: Price falls with weaker demand, lower 
freight
 Stable PVC supply in India
 Major domestic maker issues lower offer
The India PVC price fell $61/mt in the week to July 17 because 
of weaker demand, adequate availability and lower freight.
Platts assessed CFR India PVC down on the week at $919/mt.
Demand has been sluggish during the ongoing monsoon 
season with stable material supply, trade sources said.
The discussion levels were lower as buyers resisted prices 
following a drop in freight from China to India, a trader said.
A domestic producer said upcoming offers from major 
suppliers could likely be $50-$60/mt lower than last offer levels 
of around $980/mt, considering current market fundamentals.
Prices could decline in the coming days as higher levels may 
not sustain in the current market, the source said.Another producer said that there was ample PVC supply now, 
and Chinese material prices were falling amid concerns around 
the implementation of Bureau of Indian Standard certificate 
requirements in September.
Chinese cargo offers were heard in the $820-$840/mt CIF 
India range.
A major Indian domestic producer reduced its offer price 
by around $45/mt from a week earlier to about $925/mt on an 
import-parity basis.
Meanwhile, most tradable indications were heard in the $900-
$930/mt range. A selling indication from a producer was heard in 
the $920-$940/mt range, while a buying indication was heard at 
$900/mt.

Asian LDPE: Prices fall due to slower demand
 LDPE CFR FE Asia declines $10/mt
 Buyers resist high offer levels
Asian low density polyethylene prices fell in the week to July 
17 because of bearish sentiment and slower demand.
Prices in the Southeast Asian and Chinese LDPE markets 
hit near two-year highs earlier in July, driven by tight supplies 
and a lack of capacity expansion across the region, S&P Global 
Commodity Insights reported earlier.
However, prices have declined since, with buyers resisting high offer levels, and suppliers have been more willing to accept lower 
bids, said trade sources.
In China, sentiment was bearish due to low expectations of an 
economic stimulus. The traditional lull summer season has also 
put pressure on prices, said trade sources.
Platts assessed LDPE film grade down $10/mt on the week at 
$1,150/mt CFR Far East Asia on July 17 , while Chinese domestic 
LDPE fell Yuan 290/mt week on week to Yuan 10,035/mt ex-works 
east China.
China’s Wanhua Petrochemical restarted its 450,000 mt/year 
linear low density PE unit in Yantai city on July 13 after a planned 
maintenance, a company source said July 15.
The downstream unit was shut July 1 for 12 days.

China’s Wanhua Petrochemical restarted its 450,000 mt/year 
linear low density PE unit in Yantai city on July 13 after a planned 
maintenance, a company source said July 15.
The downstream unit was shut July 1 for 12 days. It is 
integrated with the company’s 1 million mt/year ethylene cracker 
in Shandong province, with a 350,000 mt/year high density PE 
unit at the same site.
China’s Dushanzi Petrochemical restarted its crude distillation 
unit and related downstream capacities in Xinjiang after about 
two months of planned maintenance, said a company source 
July 17 .
The company’s downstream PE units, including its 300,000 
mt/year HDPE line, the 300,000 mt/year LLDPE line and the 
120,000 mt/year LLDPE line have all restarted, the source said.

Asian Recycled LDPE: Prices trend downward on 
weak demand
 Prices down $10/mt on week
 Demand slow due to off-peak season, uncertain shipping 
conditions
Weak demand due to the lull summer season and high 
shipping costs have exerted downward pressure on prices in the 
Asian recycled low density polyethylene market in the week to 
July 17 .
Platts assessed Asian recycled low density polyethylene 
natural film pellets down $10/mt on the week at $790/mt FOB 
Southeast Asia July 17 .
“The demand is very slow and no one is asking for material ... I 
expect it will be soft till end July, ” said a trader who had to reduce 
his prices by 4% this week. Uncertain shipping conditions and 
escalating freight rates have also caused buyers to stay on the 
sidelines.
This has weighed on recyclers’ margins with most operating at 
a loss below breakeven price.
Despite weakened demand, tightening supply has somewhat 
helped in supporting prices, sources said. Scrap supply has been 
tightening due to increased domestic demand in regions such as 
Europe and the US.

LLDPE
Asian LLDPE: Chinese market trends down amid 
bearishness
 Weak expectations of economic stimulus pressure 
China prices
 Muted trading in Southeast Asia market
A bearish near-term outlook and falling futures prices exerted 
pressure on the Chinese linear low density polyethylene market 
across the week to July 17 .Platts assessed LLDPE CFR Far East Asia down $10/mt week 
on week at $960/mt on July 17 while the Chinese domestic 
marker was down Yuan 40/mt on the week at Yuan 8460/mt ex-
works east China.
China’s Central Committee had begun its third plenum July 
15, in which the committee would lay out a plan on the country’s 
future policy direction. On the same day, China reported its 
slowest rate of economic growth in April-June since the first 
quarter of 2023.
“Sentiments in the domestic China market have turned 
bearish due to weaker expectations that stimulus measures 
would boost the economy, ” said a Chinese trader.
In Southeast Asia, the market was quiet as participants 
awaited fresh August-shipment offers for further pricing 
directions. Buyers were also not in a rush to secure cargoes, with 
sufficient inventories heard for end-users in Thailand, Indonesia 
and Vietnam.
In plant news, China’s Wanhua Petrochemical restarted its 
450,000 mt/year LLDPE unit in Yantai city on July 13 after a 
planned maintenance, a company source said July 15.
The downstream unit was shut on July 1 for 12 days. It is 
integrated with the company’s 1 million mt/year ethylene cracker 
in Shandong province, with a 350,000 mt/year HDPE unit at the 
same site.
China’s Dushanzi Petrochemical has also restarted its crude 
distillation unit and related downstream capacities in Xinjiang 
after around two months of planned maintenance, said a 
company source July 17 .
The company’s downstream polyethylene units, including its 
300,000 mt/year high density polyethylene line, the 300,000 mt/
year linear low density polyethylene line and the 120,000 mt/year 
LLDPE line have all restarted, the source said.
They were shut May 15 and have been running since July 15, 
though the source could not confirm that all were restarted 
that day.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Asian HDPE: Trends downward amid slow demand
 Bearish sentiment in Chinese market
 Muted demand in Southeast Asia market
The Asian high density polyethylene market trended lower 
in the week to July 17 amid continued weak demand and 
ample supply.
Platts assessed HDPE CFR Far East Asia down $25/mt week 
on week at $950/mt while the Southeast Asia marker was down 
$10/mt week on week on July 17 .
End-users were not in a rush to purchase more cargoes and 
most were waiting for August shipment offers to be released next 
week, said sources.
“Demand is still weak and converters are waiting to see how 
prices are [in] these two weeks before deciding to restock, ” said 
an Indonesian source.
The congestion in the Singapore port has shown some signs 
of abating and sources were hopeful that shipping conditions 
would improve in a month’s time. However, it has not improved 
significantly and sources are still facing delays for some shipment 
cargoes.
In China, sentiment was bearish as a result of expectations 
that stimulus measures from the third Plenum Session were 
unlikely to strengthen the economy. Amid the typical lull season 
from June-July, weakening demand has exerted downward 
pressure on prices.
In plant news, China’s Dushanzi Petrochemical has restarted 
its crude distillation unit and related downstream capacities in 
Xinjiang after around two months of planned maintenance, said a 
company source July 17 .
The company’s downstream polyethylene units, including its 
300,000 mt/year high density polyethylene line, the 300,000 mt/
year linear low density polyethylene line and the 120,000 mt/year 
LLDPE line have all restarted, the source said.
They were shut May 15 and have been running since July 
15, though the source could not confirm if all were restarted 
that day.

The Asian recycled high density polyethylene market trended 
downward in the week to July 17 on weakening buying appetite 
and uncertain freight conditions.
Platts assessed recycled high density polyethylene natural 
film down $10/mt on the week at $730/mt FOB Southeast 
Asia, while recycled HDPE black blowmolding pellets was also 
assessed down $10/mt on the week at $590/mt FOB Southeast 
Asia July 17 .
Demand for imports was heard to be weak in the markets 
such as China, India and Vietnam, owing to the summer season 
lull. Freight costs and uncertain shipping conditions also 
continue to hinder buyers from making purchasing decisions, 
market sources said.
For instance, freight rates from Southeast Asia to India were 
heard at around $4,100-$5,100 for a 40-foot container, compared 
with around $500-$600/mt in the past, before freight costs 
started rising.
“It’s [freight cost] is very expensive now. so everyone is 
waiting, ” said a producer who had to reduce offer prices by 
around $10-$20/mt on slow demand.
In the virgin markets, Platts assessed HDPE film grade down 
$10/mt week on week at $1,000/mt CFR Southeast Asia July 17 
amid continued weak demand and ample supply.

PP
Asian PP: SE Asia prices fall on tepid demand, 
supply glut
 Market participants anticipate SE Asia PP price slump in Aug
 CFR FE Asia PP raffia/injection falls $5/mt on lower offers
Asian PP markets were on a downtrend in the week ending 
July 17 . Southeast Asian prices fell on bearishness, and Chinese 
prices were stable to weaker, reflecting lower import cargo offers.
China’s domestic PP raffia ex-works prices remained stable 
on the day and on the week at Yuan 7 ,650/mt July 17 . Despite 
sluggish converter demand, China domestic PP prices were 
supported by supply tightness due to maintenance shutdowns at 
several PP plants.
In terms of imports, CFR China PP raffia/injection PP prices 
were assessed $5/mt down on the day and on the week at $915/
mt July 17 , as PP homopolymer offers from the Middle East were 
heard slightly lower.
Given the current China domestic (and FOB China) market 
prices combined with surging freight costs in most regions 
globally, trade sources said the export window remains shut 
except for several locations.
“We see freight easing slightly for routes to Africa and 
South Asia. Overall, we have more allocations in Asia, but the 
competition is fierce, ” a Chinese producer said.
In Southeast Asia, Platts assessed CFR SE Asia PP prices 
down $15/mt on the week at at $960/mt July 17 , amid tepid 
buying activity.
Trade sources noted ample PP supply in the region, with 
regional producers heard to be lowering offer prices to stimulate 
buying interest from local converters.
“Generally, SE Asia converters are in a wait-and-see mode, 
anticipating freight rates to recede in August plus price 
corrections due to weak demand, ” a trader said.
“Converters are having difficulty exporting their finished 
goods, and that is affecting their demand for raw material. Their 
operating rates are lower, ” an Indonesian producer said.
Trade sources said that converters are purchasing on an “as 
needed” basis, opting to buy domestic or ASEAN cargoes over 
those from Northeast Asia or the Middle East, which incur high 
freight charges and are likely to encounter shipment delays.“We have only had limited deals and discussions in SE 
Asia lately. The July cycle is almost over, ” a Middle Eastern 
producer said.
Amid the bearish sentiment, a South Korean PP homopolymer 
cargo was heard to have been sold at a competitive price in 
Vietnam.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Asian PS: Price stable to weaker on week; GPPS, 
HIPS offer levels drop
 Offer levels for EPS stable
 SE Asia prices higher than NE Asia
Platts assessed CFR China general purpose polystyrene prices 
at $1,270/mt on July 17 , down $25/mt on the week, while high 
impact PS was assessed $15/mt lower on the week at $1,360/mt 
CFR China.Prices in China declined on the week amid lower input costs 
from a weaker styrene monomer market. Platts assessed the CFR 
China styrene monomer marker at $1,130/mt, down $12/mt on the 
week. Offer levels for both general purpose PS and high impact 
PS dropped on the week.
Market participants said that elevated freight rates have 
continued to weigh on deepsea sales. However, increasing freight 
recently for near-haul routes within Asia has led producers to 
raise offers levels for Southeast Asia.
Some trade sources said that weaker margins for container 
ships plying trade lanes in Southeast Asia have resulted in 
owners allocating cargo spaces to other trades lanes, including 
those servicing India and the Americas.
“It’s very hard to book cargo space for Thailand and Indonesia, ” 
said a producer in Taiwan. Trading sources said that container 
freight from Northeast Asia to Southeast Asia varied widely 
depending on demand, with southbound cargoes around $40/
mt for Vietnam unloading, compared with up to $100/mt for 
Indonesia unloading.
In the expandable PS market, producers were keeping offer 
levels stable as freight rates remain elevated. “Deepsea freight 
has stopped increasing, but near-haul freight within Asia has 
continued to climb, ” said a producer based in Taiwan.
In the Indian market, some participants were bearish about 
the styrenics chain outlook and prices along the value chain. A 
trader said that Chinese-origin general purpose PS cargoes are 
facing increasing competition from Iranian-origin cargoes, which 
were heard offered in the $1,280-$1,290/mt CFR India range.
“That’s barely above the FOB China value. Freight from China 
should be around $100-$110/mt, ” the trader said, shutting out 
most Chinese-origin cargoes for now.

Asian ABS: Stable demand, high freight costs keep 
prices steady
 Upstream input costs fall
 China operating rates around 64.5%
Asian acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene prices remained stable 
on the week July 17 , as producers report stable demand, while 
continued tightness in container freight markets have kept prices 
steady despite lower input costs for producers.
Platts assessed the ABS CFR China and CFR Southeast Asia 
markers at $1,445/mt and $1,465/mt, both stable on the week on 
July 17 .
On the feedstock front, input costs for Asian ABS fell, with 
both acrylonitrile and styrene monomer closing lower on the 
week. According to calculations from S&P Global Commodity 
Insights, feedstock costs fell $18/mt compared to the previous 
week. Butadiene remained stable week on week at $1,650/mt 
CFR China July 17 , while acrylonitrile falling $25/mt to $1,245/mt 
CFR Fareast Asia, last assessed July 16. Styrene monomer fell 
$12/mt to $1,130/mt CFR China on July 17 .
Buying demand remained stable, but tighter availability in 
container freight markets have kept prices supported, according 
to market sources.
A producer in Northeast Asia added that decreasing operating 
rates in China also contributed to supporting prices.
In China, operating rates in the week ending July 11 were heard 
at around 64.5%, falling 4.5% from the previous week.
“ABS export demand is still quite good, ” said a polymer trader 
based in China.

Despite downstream participants paring back on operation 
rates, PTA producers are unlikely to follow the same lines,

something wrong with facility, ” the producer said.
Meanwhile, the upcoming typhoon season could greatly

“Now China is worried about the impact of the typhoons, 
which has caused a strain on the PTA spot, ” the trader said.
Most Chinese PTA plants are located on the east coast of the 
country making them more prone to typhoons, sources said.
At this time of the year, ports prepare to stock PTA supplies 
for exports and typhoons could severely disrupt activities, some 
sources said.

Asian Acetic Acid/VAM: AA prices rise on tight 
supply, VAM slips
 FOB China up $14/mt on week
 Tepid demand in VAM markets
AA/VAM: Low inventory and tight spot availability led the 
decline in Asian acetic acid prices July 18.
In China, AA inventory across the country was 130,000 
mt in the week ended July 18 and was deemed to be low by 
market sources.
Additionally, the availability of spot cargoes for the Indian 
export market was tight, market sources said.
As a result, FOB China offers were higher at $365-$370/mt 
July 18 compared to $355-$360/mt FOB the week before.
Platts assessed FOB China $14/mt higher week on week at 
$364/mt on July 18.
In the Asian vinyl acetate monomer market, demand was 
heard to be sluggish.An offer for the Southeast Asia VAM market was heard at 
$790/mt CFR.
There were unconfirmed reports that some deals were 
concluded in the low $700s/mt CFR SE Asia, but this could 
not be immediately verified.
Upstream, CFR Northeast Asia ethylene prices were 
stable on the week at $857/mt July 18, data from S&P Global 
Commodity Insights showed.

South Asian Acetic Acid/VAM: Acetic acid rises 
on stronger Chinese market, VAM demand soft
 AA, VAM Kandla port stock drops
 CFR offers rise on higher FOB China prices
AA: India’s domestic ex-tank acetic acid prices improved 
slightly, with offers heard around Rupee 35-35.50/kg at 
Kandla port and Rupee 36.50-36.75/kg at Mumbai port.
Slight gains in ex-tank prices (from Rupee 34/kg levels last 
heard) were due to some reduction in port inventories and a 
rise in international prices, according to a market source.
Meanwhile, Indian producer GNFC was heard operating 
at 110% efficiency, with its ex-factory prices currently around 
Rupee 36/kg, a company source said.

AA: India’s domestic ex-tank acetic acid prices improved 
slightly, with offers heard around Rupee 35-35.50/kg at 
Kandla port and Rupee 36.50-36.75/kg at Mumbai port.
Slight gains in ex-tank prices (from Rupee 34/kg levels last 
heard) were due to some reduction in port inventories and a 
rise in international prices, according to a market source.
Meanwhile, Indian producer GNFC was heard operating 
at 110% efficiency, with its ex-factory prices currently around

Acetic acid inventory at Kandla port was at 44,386 mt as

levels, data from market sources showed. However, the levels 
were still much higher than the average inventory of 25,000-
30,000 mt, traders said.
“Indian traders didn’t book much spot due to heavy 
inventory and significant loss making. Number of hands having

Asian PET: Stable to softer amid thin spot activity
 Buyers conservative amid seasonal lull and high freight rates
 China’s polyester operating rate estimated at 86%
Asian polyethylene terephthalate markets were stable to 
softer in the week to July 17 , putting an end to its two-week 
consecutive price uptick amid thin spot activity
Offers from Northeast Asia remained steady while Southeast 
Asia saw a slight decrease, as sources attributed it to increased 
inventory pressure in Southeast Asia, with demand conditions 
remaining largely unchanged from the previous week.
Due to the seasonal demand lull and high freight rates, 
buyers are more conservative and spot trading activity has been 
reduced, sources said. However, producers are still hesitant to 
lower offers due to persistently poor margins with certain extent 
of buyers’ acceptance at current levels, one of the traders added.
Meanwhile, prices in the polyester and yarn sector fell in the 
week leading to July 17 as buying appetite decreased with a 
slowdown in end-product demand.
Sources noted that operating rates at China’s polyester 
plants were last estimated at 86.1% on July 17 , from 87% the 
previous week, with expectation of further downward adjustment 
on the back of inventory build amid the market’s seasonally 
slow demand.
Upstream, MEG fell $5/mt on the week to $547/mt CFR China 
July 17 , while PTA fell $10/mt to $758/mt CFR China over the same 
period, Commodity Insights data showed.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Recycled PET
Asian R-PET: FOB SE Asia stable amid freight 
challenges
 Demand from East Asia, Middle East robust
 FOB SE Asia R-PET offers stable on the week
Recycled polyethylene terephthalate FOB Southeast Asia 
prices held steady in the week ending July 17 , reflecting sustained 
demand from East Asia and the Middle East.
Platts assessed R-PET clear flakes and premium-grade 
flakes stable on the day and on the week at $845/mt and $940/
mt, respectively. Food-grade R-PET pellets were also assessed 
steady at $1,250/mt.
According to market sources, import demand for FOB R-PET 
clear flakes (premium grade) remains robust, with several 
recyclers reportedly having concluded deals for their July 
sales cycles.
“It is difficult to ship large loads, but smaller loads are doable. 
Exports to the Middle East are still workable. Demand is still 
there, ” a Southeast Asian recycler said.
At the same time, buyers from Europe and North America 
were heard to be taking a wait-and-see approach, given the 
higher availability of R-PET material during the summer season 
in those markets and lower East-West arbitrage due to high 
freight rates.
Freight quotes from Southeast Asia to Europe were heard 
unchanged, around the $9,700/FEU mark, while freight from 
Southeast Asia to the Middle East was heard to be stabilizing at 
around $3,500-$4,000/FEU.
On the supply side, Southeast Asian recyclers mostly retained 
their offers this week, while PET bottle bale feedstock costs were 
largely unchanged.
PET bale prices were stable at $580-$640/mt in Indonesia and 
$540-$560/mt in Malaysia, but fluctuated slightly at around Baht 
19.5-21.5/kg in Thailand, reflecting disrupted collections during 
the rainy season.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

This rationale applies to symbol(s) <RPTSE00>.India R-PET: Prices rise on firmer domestic demand, 
higher indications
 Better domestic demand supports export offers
 Export demand queries continue
The Indian recycled polyethylene terephthalate market 
strengthened on firmer domestic demand supporting 
export offers.
Platts assessed FOB India R-PET flakes price up $11/mt on 
the week at $941/mt and pellets were up $10/mt on the week at 
$1,250/mt July 17 .
“Indian domestic R-PET pellets prices are much higher 
compared with the export offers, ” an Indian pellets producer 
said. “Limited approved producers of pellets with appropriate 
certifications catering to the Indian demand are keeping 
domestic prices elevated. ”
A Middle East buyer of Indian flakes said: “We are looking for 
the flakes for our fiber usage and checking with Indian producers 
for appropriate offers, ” adding, “Offers at the moment are wide 
ranging, and we are hearing some uptick in the flakes’ prices from 
Southeast Asia as well. ”
Another Indian producer said: “Indian pellets prices are well 
supported from robust Indian demand, which is why selling at 
lower prices in [the] export market would be hard for us, but we 
continue to receive export queries. ”
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

MMA, PMMA
Asian MMA and PMMA: Prices rise to be capped by 
weak downstream
 MMA supplies remain tight as downstream weakens
 Operation rates set to decrease
Methyl methacrylate prices remained stable on the day on 
July 17 , with the China assessment at $2,080/mt CFR China and 
the Southeast Asia assessment at $2,230/mt CFR SE Asia.
According to a trader in China, supplies of MMA continued to 
remain tight.
July 19, 2024 Asian Petrochemicalscan27 © 2024 by S&P Global Inc. All rights reserved.
However, sources said the tightness in supplies did little to 
boost prices.
“The supply [of MMA] remains tight but demand was weak 
from downstream due to slow downstream market activity, ” the 
trader in China said.
In the PMMA market, sentiment remained slightly depressed 
despite stable demand cues, sources said.
The high costs of MMA were harming the PMMA market, the 
trader in China said.
Additionally, the high costs of freight would further cap buying 
interest and worsen the ongoing situation in the MMA and PMMA 
markets, the trader in China added.
“My personal opinion is [that it is] difficult for improvement 
from downstream as other bigger challenge [arises] from [high] 
ocean freight, ” the trader said.
Meanwhile, plant operation rates in China were set to move 
lower, with production appetite looking increasingly weak, 
sources said.
A source in Asia said that Chinese MMA production plants 
could scale back operation rates to around 45%-48% as well.
The drop in operation rates could be attributed to sluggish 
downstream activity, the same source added.
PMMA prices were also stable, with the China assessment 
at $2,380/mt CFR China and the SE Asia assessment stable at 
$2,460/mt CFR SE Asia.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

Platts proposes launching East China propane, butane physical 
assessments from Oct 1
Platts, part of S&P Global Commodity Insights, is proposing to 
launch propane and butane physical assessments on a CFR East 
China basis from Oct. 1, 2024, amid an increase in LPG inflows 
into the region.
Platts is proposing to publish four new daily CFR East China 
LPG physical assessments and their respective monthly averages. 
The four new daily assessments would include assessments 
for propane and butane cargoes with a minimum size of 11,000 
mt and a maximum size of 44,000 mt, for delivery 20-35 days 
forward, on an outright basis as well as their cash differentials to 
the front-month Saudi Aramco Contract Price (M1) derivatives.
DISCHARGE PORTS: The proposed assessments would reflect 
cargoes delivered into Ningbo. Deliveries into other safe and 
sound ports in Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces of East China may 
be considered for inclusion in the assessments, normalized to a 
Ningbo basis.
PRODUCT SPECIFICATIONS: The CFR East China propane 
and butane assessments would reflect the existing Platts North 
Asia propane and butane specifications. For full details of the 
specification, please see http:/ /plts.co/V0Ax30ru2Yi.
TIMESTAMP: The proposed CFR East China propane and 
butane assessments would reflect the tradable value of these

Platts proposes to launch North Asia propane derivatives 
assessments
Platts, part of S&P Global Commodity Insights, is proposing 
to launch a series of price assessments reflecting North Asia 
propane derivatives, inter-regional propane derivatives and inter-
product derivative spreads from Oct. 1, 2024.
Platts is proposing to publish Month 1, Month 2, Month 3, and 
front-quarter North Asia propane derivative assessments, along 
with North Asia propane/Saudi Aramco Contract Price propane 
derivative spreads and North Asia propane/Mean of Platts Japan 
naphtha derivative spreads on the same forward strip.
TIMESTAMP: The North Asia propane derivatives assessments 
and the North Asia propane/Saudi Aramco CP propane derivative 
spreads would reflect the close of Asia LPG trading at 5:00 pm 
Singapore time (0900 GMT). The North Asia propane/MOPJ 
naphtha derivative spreads would be calculated from the 
corresponding Platts assessments at their respective close.
VOLUME: The new propane outright assessments and 
derivative spreads would reflect a tradeable clip size of 5,000 mt.
The proposed North Asia propane derivatives assessments 
would be based on bids, offers, or trades seen during the Platts 
Market on the Close assessment process. In the absence of any 
bids, offers or trades in the MOC, information from derivative 
exchanges or heard in over-the-counter markets may be taken 
into consideration.
Platts has established clearly defined timing guidelines 
and standards of incrementability that apply when publishing 
bids and offers during the MOC process in order to ensure an 
orderly and transparent price assessment process. Details 
can be found in this guide: https:/ /www.spglobal.com/
commodityinsights/PlattsContent/_assets/_files/en/our-
methodology/methodology-specifications/oil-timing-increment-
guidelines.pdf .Please send comments and questions to 
asia_products@spglobal.com and pricegroup@spglobal.com 
by Aug. 30, 2024. For written comments, please provide a clear 
indication if comments are not intended for publication by Platts 
for public viewing. Platts will consider all comments received and 
will make comments not marked as confidential available upon 
request.
Platts changes the publishing schedule for India/South Asia 
chemical assessments
Platts, part of S&P Global Commodity Insights, will publish 
its India/South Asia chemical assessments in line with the India 
publishing schedule beginning July 8, 2024.
These assessments followed the Singapore publishing 
schedule previously.
From July 8, 2024, daily India/South Asia chemical 
assessments will not be published during India public holidays. 
Weekly assessments falling on Indian public holidays will be 
published one day in advance.
For example, for 2024, weekly assessments for Aug. 15, Oct. 2, 
Oct. 31 and Nov. 15 will be published one day in advance on Aug. 
14, Oct.1, Oct. 29 and Nov. 14, respectively.

Platts to observe India and Singapore publishing schedules for 
toluene CFR India outright assessment
Platts, part of S&P Global Commodity Insights, has decided 
to publish the outright CFR India toluene assessment in line 
with the Singapore and India publishing schedules, effective July 
23, 2024.

is derived off an additional premium to the FOB Korea toluene 
marker, will not be published when there is a holiday either in 
Singapore or India.Platts will still assess the toluene differential between CFR

as announced in a separate note.

Benzene
Asian Benzene: Prices fall with weaker upstream 
markets
 US-Asia spread at $130/mt
 JG Summit releases term sale tender for 15,000 mt or 
75,000 mt
Asian benzene prices fell $5/mt on the session to $998.33/mt 
FOB Korea, amid weaker performance in upstream markets.
Upstream, the front month ICE Brent futures contract fell 
26 cents/b on the session to $85.10/b. Platts assessed the 
C+F Japan naphtha marker $6.25/mt lower on the session at 
$699.50/mt.
Two deals were observed during the Platts Market On Close 
assessment process for FOB Korea, where Tricon bought H2 
August FOB Korea from TotalEnergies at $1,006/mt, and GS 
Caltex bought September FOB Korea from TotalEnergies at 
$994.50/mt.
Market participants expect supply to be more plentiful, with 
South Korean producers coming back from turnaround activity 
and also higher inventories in China. While no firm bids or offers 
were heard on the day for CFR China, market sources suggested 
that recent discussions were heard at premiums of around $37-
$38/mt against the September weekly Mean of Platts Korea base 
price for September arrival cargoes.
“Supply feels more plentiful nowadays, ” said a buyer in China.
Amid a slowdown in demand as downstream units in China are 
undergoing a turnaround season, some expect prices to continue 
the downward trend, though others have pointed out that an 
opening arbitrage opportunity to the US would provide prices 
some level of support.
The Asia-US spread, calculated as the difference between the 
FOB Korea marker and the US DDP M2 marker, stands at $130/mt 
as of the Asian close on July 19.
In tender news, the Philippines’ JG Summit Olefins Corporation 
has released a benzene term sale tender, FOB Batangas, for 
either 15,000 mt or 75,000 mt, loading over October 2024 
to December 2024 or over October 2024 to December 2026, 
according to market sources.
Customs statistics from South Korea indicate that the country 
exported 223,187 mt of benzene in June, increasing 11.6% from 
the previous month but decreasing 15.1% compared to the same 
period in 2023.

India Toluene: Limited import activity amid healthy 
inventory
 Domestic prices heard stable
 Sep ICE Brent crude futures slip 26 cents/b
Domestic ex-Kandla toluene prices remained stable on the 
day July 19, reportedly at Rupee 83-84/kg, while ex-Mumbai 
prices were at Rupee 85/kg.
Domestic sellers are trying to sell at higher prices because the 
material previously imported at a lower cost has depleted, and 
they are now offering material that was imported at a higher cost, 
an India-based trader said.
Buyer’s interest remains subdued, despite sellers significantly 
reducing their offers, according to a trader. He added that the 
healthy domestic inventory and weak demand resisted buyers 
from importing. Around 8,000 mt of toluene was expected to 
unload from South Korea in the week starting July 22.
Meanwhile, a seller mentioned that there was resistance to sell 
to India at a premium below $100/mt. “We are looking to sell into 
Southeast Asia market as prices are now almost similar to India 
and netbacks from selling into India are thin. Margins are negative 
for sellers when selling at $100/mt premium, ” a trader said.
The outright price was assessed at $977/mt, down $1/mt on 
the day, based on the FOB Korea marker. The FOB Korea marker 
was assessed at $879/mt, down $1/mt on the day.
Front-month ICE September Brent futures slipped 26 cents/b 
from the previous close to $85.10/b at the Asian close July 19.

Asian Solvent MX: FOB Korea falls $23/mt on week 
as offers emerge
 Aromatics markets mostly lower
 China MX inventory shrinks further
Asian solvent-grade mixed xylene fell $23/mt week on week 
to $877/mt FOB Korea on July 19, with other markers also moving 
lower amid generally lower prices in related markets and as 
offers for August-loading cargoes were unchallenged by bids.Asian aromatics markets were mostly moving lower week on 
week with naphtha prices weakening over the period. Toluene 
FOB Korea shed $9/mt at $879/mt on July 19, while isomer-grade 
mixed xylene fell $12.50/mt to $906.50/mt FOB Korea.
However, the markets were not all looking soft as import prices 
to China seemed workable at the moment, with buy ideas for 
August arrivals heard around $900-$915/mt CFR China. In China, 
the inventory level of MX was shrinking further with some market 
sources saying levels in east China were below or just above 
30,000 mt, compared to around 35,000 mt the week before.
But the Southeast Asia market still seemed soft and 
relatively thin.
In related market news, South Korea’s Lotte Chemical shut its 
naphtha-fed steam cracker and related benzene-toluene-xylene 
unit in Daesan early July 18 following a power failure, sources 
close to the company said.
The company’s steam cracker is able to produce 1.1 million mt/
year of ethylene and 550,000 mt/year of propylene. A company 
source said its butadiene production is also coming down 
following the emergency shutdown. The company has a 190,000 
mt/year butadiene plant in Daesan.
“The NCC and BTX units are both down, ” one of the sources 
said. “Restart is expected on July 20, ” the source added.
Another source close to the company said: “I know that it is 
the gas turbine generator [trip]. ”
The Daesan unit was running at 80% capacity in July, similar 
to its BTX unit in Yeosu, S&P Global Commodity Insights reported 
earlier. Inventories have been low, with both units holding around 
5,000 mt of toluene, sources said.
The aromatics plant in Daesan can produce 240,000 mt/year 
of benzene, 120,000 mt/year of toluene and 60,000 mt/year of 
mixed xylenes.

Paraxylene
Asian Paraxylene: Prices drop as supply concerns 
resurface
 Curbing supplies remains a challenge
 PTA producers grapple with high freight rates
Asian paraxylene prices fell on the day July 19 amid fresh 
concerns of excess supplies prevailing in the Asian market.
Platts assessed Asian PX down $3.83/mt on the day 
at $1,008.50/mt CFR Taiwan/China on July 19, S&P Global 
Commodity Insights data showed.
PX prices declined, shedding light on the excess spot volumes 
in the market with a limited likelihood of any major reduction in 
production.
A trader in Singapore said that despite the weakness in 
demand for PX, producers may find it hard to slash production.
“For PX and benzene, it is difficult to cut operation rates as 
mogas [is] not performing, ” the trader said.
As the hype around gasoline blending and the US summer 
driving season is over, producers are expected to channel 
aromatics production around Asia itself, market sources said.
“From November [trading cycle] onward, I don’t see PX and benzene going to [the] gasoline pool, ” the trader in 
Singapore said.
Meanwhile, purified terephthalic acid producers are 
concerned as container freight costs have surged sharply, a 
producer in Asia said.
The sharp rise in container shipping costs is now pushing 
producers to opt for breakbulk shipping instead, some 
shipbrokers said.
“I think everyone is switching to breakbulk due to container 
fees being high, ” the producer in Asia said.
Furthermore, the rise in freight rates is impacting buying 
trends as well, the producer added.
“Because they need volumes for breakbulk, customers are 
trying to combine [import] volumes for two months [of] loading, ” 
the producer noted.
The Asian PX Platts Market on Close assessment process 
July 19 saw several bids and offers for September- and October-
delivery cargoes.

Asian Iso-MX: Falls $11.50-$12.50/mt on week with 
lower PX
 PX falls $17 .17/mt on week
 China inventory shrinks further
Asian isomer-grade mixed xylene fell $12.50/mt on the week 
to $906.50/mt FOB Korea, to $921.50/mt CFR Taiwan and down 
$11.50/mt at $931.50/mt CFR China on July 19, with downstream 
paraxylene also moving lower from the previous week.
PX was down $17 .17/mt at $1,008.50/mt CFR Taiwan/China on 
July 19, and the PX price also moved lower by $3.83/mt day on day.
As a result, the PX-MX spread ended the week at $102/mt, 
narrowing from $106.67/mt on July 12.
A trader said the shrinking spread between PX and MX could 
be the result of increased run rates at PX plants, which were 
consuming more MX.
In China, the inventory level of MX was shrinking further with 
some market sources saying levels in east China were below 
or just above 30,000 mt, compared to around 35,000 mt the 
week before.
The Platts domestic China ex-tank assessment was assessed 
down Yuan 23.33/mt day on day at Yuan 7 ,835/mt on July 19, or about $943.50/mt on an import-parity basis.
Meanwhile in news during the week, South Korea’s exports 
of isomer-MX rose 3.2% year on year in the first half of 2024 to 
581,431 mt as exports, especially to the US, more than doubled by 
136,308 mt to 212,253 mt, customs data released July 15 shows.
A bullish outlook for the gasoline peak demand season led to 
large volumes of MX being shipped to the US early in the year, 
but with gasoline margins and gasoline-related demand tumbling 
over May-June, the arbitrage to the US has since closed and the 
outlook shifted to a bearish gear.

The Platts domestic China ex-tank assessment was assessed 
down Yuan 23.33/mt day on day at Yuan 7 ,835/mt on July 19, or about $943.50/mt on an import-parity basis.
Meanwhile in news during the week, South Korea’s exports 
of isomer-MX rose 3.2% year on year in the first half of 2024 to 
581,431 mt as exports, especially to the US, more than doubled by 
136,308 mt to 212,253 mt, customs data released July 15 shows.
A bullish outlook for the gasoline peak demand season led to 
large volumes of MX being shipped to the US early in the year, 
but with gasoline margins and gasoline-related demand tumbling 
over May-June, the arbitrage to the US has since closed and the 
outlook shifted to a bearish gear.
On the flip side, exports from South Korea to China over the 
same period plunged 40.9% year on year to 213,122 mt, while 
exports to Taiwan and India have both increased.
South Korea’s isomer-MX imports, which are almost entirely 
from Japan, also shrunk in the first six months of the year by

widening the spread to the downstream China domestic styrene 
monomer to Yuan 920/mt. Platts assessed the China domestic ethylbenzene spot price down at Yuan 8,611/mt.

lower operating rates for ABS and PS plants. The reduced demand 
has led to a surplus of styrene in the market, which typically puts 
downward pressure on styrene prices.
Styrene inventory in China was increasing week on week, 
trading sources said. In East China, the stocks rose by 5,900 mt 
from a week earlier to 38,700 mt in the week ended July 19, trading 
sources added.
“[Some are] struggling from high inventory issue, which is a 
direct impact of low demand in India, ” a trader said.
There was an H2 August-September buying indication heard at 
around CFR China plus $15/mt on CFR Korea basis, sources said. No 
trades were reported.

on the day July 19.

Asian caprolactam prices were assessed $5/mt lower in the

Upstream, benzene prices fell $17 .34/mt on the week to

week, with Platts’ last assessment of ammonia prices at $460/mt 
Far East Asia on July 17 .

ending July 18, with muted activity heard.
In China, price discussions have fallen sharply, said market 
sources, with the rest of the market possibility following suit in 
the coming weeks.
“I’ve heard that the domestic China market has fallen to an equivalent of $1,550/mt, next week the CFR Far East Asia spot

market source.

support from stable demand in downstream nylon-6 resins, which 
could limit the fall in prices as caprolactam starts to lose support 
from falling benzene prices.

offers but my price ideas are on the conservative side, ” said a 
buyer in Taiwan, who added that an offer around $1,660/mt was 
received this week.

Methanol
Asian Methanol: Prices soften on ample supply, 
tepid demand
 SE Asia end users focus on term obligations
 Higher palm oil prices deter demand for biodiesel, methanol
 Sep ZCE down Yuan 80/mt on week
Asian methanol prices closed the week July 19 lower on the 
back of ample supply and slow demand.
A surfeit of Middle East cargoes heading for the Indian 
methanol market led some sellers to reconsider their positions 
and offer some cargoes in the Southeast Asian methanol market 
for August.A deal for a cargo arriving in the second-half of August was 
concluded at $352/mt CFR Singapore, which was superseded by 
an offer at $350/mt CFR Singapore.
Spot demand for methanol at Southeast Asian main ports 
was tepid as end users were committed to fulfilling their term 
obligations or had no space in their tanks for spot cargoes.
Methanol demand from regional biodiesel producers was 
tepid as palm methyl ester prices were $305.79/mt higher than 
gasoil, data from S&P Global Commodity Insights showed.
“It’s just cheaper to burn gasoil than biodiesel, ” said a trader.
Methanol is one of the feedstocks of biodiesel.
In China, an early-week rally fizzled out midweek when market 
data showed a 6.23% on week rise in methanol inventory to 
680,900 mt on July 17 .
Domestic methanol prices in east China fell for three 
continuous days as expectations of ample methanol supply 
arriving in China in August weighed on the market sentiment.
“China imports are expected to be higher in August, ” a 
trader said.
The actively-traded September methanol futures contract on 
the Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange fell Yuan 32/mt or $4.40/mt 
day on day from the previous close and Yuan 80/mt lower on the 
week at Yuan 2,493/mt July 19.
Platts assessed CFR China $2/mt lower day on day at 
$286.50/mt and CFR Southeast Asia methanol price down $1/mt 
on the day at $350/mt July 19.
Platts is part of S&P Global Commodity Insights.

India Methanol: Rebounds slightly following losses 
in a weak market
 Iranian volumes expected to land in Aug
 Weak buying interest weighs on prices
Indian methanol prices rose marginally July 19, after sharp 
declines the previous week, with market fundamentals weak amid 
expectations of cargo inflows from Iran in August.
Indian traders were under selling pressure, with local ex-
tank discussions heard in the Rupee 25-25.25/kg range at the 
Kandla and Mumbai ports. “End-users are bidding too low. 
We are struggling to sell even at Rupee 25.25/kg ex-tank, ” an 
importer said.
Hazira port offers were heard in the Rupee 25.75-26/kg range, 
against buying interest heard at Rupee 25.50/kg. Import parity levels were in the $279-$285/mt range, Platts data showed. “We 
have stopped selling and [are] trying to buy material from local 
traders amid a weaker ex-tank market. The Kandla port inventory 
is concentrated in few hands, ” a trader said.
About 38,560 mt methanol was expected to arrive in Mumbai 
in the week ending July 26.

About 38,560 mt methanol was expected to arrive in Mumbai

expected to arrive at the Kandla port by July 22, according to 
trade sources. “August is long with several cargoes from Iran are 
expected into India, ” said a trade source.
Meanwhile, material lifting from ports remained consistent 
with several auctions heard concluded in the week ended July 19.
CFR discussions were heard in a wide range. A 5,000 mt 
second-half August-arrival trade was heard at $275/mt CFR India, 
letter of credit 30 days. Another 3,000 mt was heard sold on bond 
transfer basis to an end-user. An H1 August loading, Aug. 15-20 
arrival, 5000 mt trade was done at $283/mt CFR India. Two bids 
were heard — one at $273/mt and another at $280/mt CFR India.
“We think the market has already hit a bottom, ” an 
importer said.
Sellers were on the sidelined because of weaker price 
realization in India. “We would prefer not to sell and wait, ” a 
trader said.
Platts assessed the CFR India methanol price higher by 50 
cents/mt on the day at $280.50/mt on July 19.
In the adjacent market, Platts assessed CFR China methanol 
down $2/mt on the day at $286.50/mt and CFR Southeast Asia
